bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilbur A. Sawyer, July 3, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Sawyer that he had never intended for him to personally approach Rockefeller on his behalf. He requests a letter of introduction to present to Rockefeller or one of Rockefeller's associates.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilbur A. Sawyer, July 3, 1947
div1.opener:
July 3, 1947
Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer
Chairman, Program Committee
Division of International Conferences
Department of State
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Mr. Sawyer:
div1.p:
I am very glad to have your letter of June 26. I really
wondered what happened to my letter of May 12. I was sorry not to
have gotten it before I was in New York. Doctor Sawyer, I am
afraid that you misunderstood my letter. I certainly am not asking
you to approach Mr. Rockefeller, yourself. That would be a great
imposition on my part.

I was merely hoping that you could tell me how I might
contact him. Perhaps you could give me a letter of introduction to
him or to one of his associates. I have been told that one of his
secretaries handles the matter of his benevolences and perhaps a
letter to that person would be what I need. If you think you can
dictate a letter in good conscience, I would appreciate it. I have
no other possible contact with Mr. Rockefeller and a letter from you
just to one of his associates if not to Mr. Rockefeller himself
introducing me briefly would be most helpful. I can carry on from
there by correspondence and later on with a visit with him or one of
his associates some time this fall.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:ktb
